Budget; EDS: ADDS more quotes, details of drought conditions; Member Photo Requested; INDEX: Health, Environment, Agriculture; HL:Alberta forest fire north of Edmonton continued to burn out of control Friday</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By John Cotter</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>EDMONTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>EDMONTON (CP) - Acrid smoke from a raging forest fire continued to drift across central Alberta Friday as crews fought to keep the blaze from consuming the hamlet of Chisholm.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Despite tinder dry conditions and out-of-control flames within three kilometres of the community, provincial fire officials had no plans to evacuate the area 200 kilometres north of Edmonton.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- "The conditions are very extreme,'' said Anna Kauffman, spokeswoman for the Resource Development department.</p><p>"But there has not been too much concern about evacuation at this point.''</p><p>However, Kauffman said 12 families living north of the nearby community of Flatbush have left their homes as a precaution due to intense smoke in the area.</p><p>"Not because of fire danger but because of health concerns,'' she said.</p><p>One family, Doug and Maureen Schiller and their sister-in-law Rachel, scrambled to gather up their farm animals and keepsakes before leaving.</p><p>"I'm packing up wedding pictures, wedding albums, my husband's baby book, anything I can't replace,'' Rachel Schiller said as she watched the flames off in the distance.</p><p>"People are taking our cattle for us. And we don't even care where they go. We've had to move out 45 head and their calves.''</p><p>Farmer Elwin Whyte said the flames shot 30 metres feet in the air within a few kilometres from his wheat and barley operation on Thursday as the fire leaped from tree top to tree top.</p><p>Whyte sent his wife and younger children to safety but stayed behind with an older son to dig trenches and water down the outbuildings.</p><p>He said the situation was "pretty scary.''</p><p>"I was worried. You get quite excited.''</p><p>The 40-square-kilometre fire broke out Wednesday near the CNR rail line, but the cause of the blaze is still under investigation, Kauffman said.</p><p>The area is mainly wooded hills and farmland. Drought conditions and moderate winds have made it difficult to contain the fire, she said.</p><p>Hundreds of gas wells are in the area, but they were shut down as a precaution before the flames got too close.</p><p>More than 160 firefighters, including helicopters, are battling the blaze.</p><p>A total of 17 fires were burning in the province Friday.</p><p>The dry conditions prompted the province to extend a ban on open fires from a line between Peace River and Lac la Biche in northern Alberta to points just above the U.S. border.</p><p>"The continued drying trend will result in a build up of high to extreme forest fire hazard conditions,'' said a provincial release. "These conditions will increase the potential for out-of-control fires.''</p><p>So far this spring Alberta has received only trace amounts of moisture instead of normal rainfall levels of between 50 and 100 millimetres.</p><p>Major rivers south of northern Alberta are running at three-quarters to less than half of normal water levels.</p><p>The lack of moisture and a near record low mountain snowpack coupled with a dry winter and two previous dry summers has officials bracing for one of the worst agricultural droughts since the 1930's.</p><p>"Almost 90 per cent of the provincial agriculture area doesn't have enough soil moisture for annual cropping this year,'' said Alberta Agriculture spokesman Lloyd Andruchow.</p><p>"These conditions are threatening to impact what is a $7 billion primary agricultural industry in Alberta.''</p><p>The government is expected to announce additional drought support programs if the province doesn't receive significant rainfall by the end of June.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Joining us on the<br/>phone with the latest on this volatile situation is the mayor, Greg<br/>Kamenka.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Greg, thank you very much for joining us.</p><p>KAMENKA: Good morning. You're welcome.</p><p>O'REGAN: First of all, give us the current status of the fire<br/>right now.</p><p>KAMENKA: The current status is that it's still on the edge of<br/>town [unintelligible] … we are watching and waiting. The fire is<br/>burning. It's not under control yet, but as long as the winds are<br/>blowing away from Lillooet we're in no immediate danger. If the<br/>winds shift and come in the other direction it would turn around<br/>and come right back into Lillooet. And that's when the danger<br/>certainly would be obvious [overtalk] --</p><p>O'REGAN: Mr. Mayor, how far away is that? How many kilometres?</p><p>KAMENKA: Three kilometres from town.</p><p>O'REGAN: And the hope is that it will burn back on itself?</p><p>KAMENKA: If it does come back on itself it'll probably jump and<br/>come back into town, if it changes direction. As long as it stays<br/>where it is or progresses in the direction away from town we aren't<br/>in immediate danger.</p><p>O'REGAN: How many firefighters are on the scene right now?</p><p>KAMENKA: In excess of 220. They're coming in continually from<br/>various areas in BC now. The forestry department is bringing in<br/>various attack crews and outside contractors as well.</p><p>O'REGAN: How are people doing there? They must be just sitting<br/>and waiting, I guess, with the car packed up. Is that the case?</p><p>KAMENKA: That's about all we can do. People with respiratory<br/>problems have left town. Some of the people with young children<br/>and animals have moved away from the community. But otherwise, the<br/>Lillooet residents have experienced it in the past. Every 10 or 20<br/>or 30 years there's a fire of various magnitudes. And so, they're<br/>quite prepared for it. They're watching and waiting at the present<br/>time.</p><p>O'REGAN: How bad is the smoke right now? Tell me about the<br/>visibility there in the town.</p><p>KAMENKA: The visibility is [unintelligible] … at the base of<br/>the mountain. It's not too bad. It's difficult to breathe<br/>sometimes. There is an inversion up over the fire. The smoke is<br/>very, very heavy. It makes it almost impossible for the<br/>firefighters to go in with helicopters and fixed-wing aircraft<br/>until that smoke clears. It's just too dangerous.</p><p>O'REGAN: Mr. Mayor, thank you very much for joining us this<br/>morning. And we wish you and the entire community there nothing<br/>but the best of luck right now.</p><p>KAMENKA: Good. Thank you very much for your interest.</p><p>O'REGAN: Thank you.<br/></p><p>Here's a look at the costs of last year's wildfires in British<br/>Columbia. Three people died, 334 homes were destroyed, 45,000<br/>people evacuated, and damages reaching $700-million.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5PHT-W5J1-F105-615K-00000-00Campfires allowed again in rural Maple Ridge2017-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:06ZLexisNexisNEWSCampfires allowed again in rural Maple RidgePhil Melnychuk

Cool weather and rain has allowed the Maple Ridge Fire Department to cancel its burning ban at noon on Tuesday, Sept. 19.

The ban was implemented on July 7, after this summer's heat wave turned local forests tinder dry and led to a forest fire danger rating of extreme. The ban prohibited people from having campfires in Maple Ridge's open-to-burn areas, mainly the rural areas.

Fire chief Howard Exner said the forest fire danger rating now sits at moderate after more than 10 millimetres of rain fell in the last few days. According to the guage at the fire department, 3.2 mm fell on the weekend, 1.2 mm on Monday and 7.2 mm just on Tuesday morning alone.

During the summer, the department issued as many as 75 tickets to those who ignored the fire ban, possibly risking a raging wildfire in dense coastal forests near homes and businesses.

But with the ban now lifted, Exner said it doesn't mean there's a free for all. Campfires only are allowed in the open-to-burn areas.

Exner expects conditions not to change much for the rest of the year. "I think it would be hard for us to climb back up to extreme again."

Exner said that people can go on to the city's online mapping system to see if their property remains in the open-to-burning area or is now part of a built-up area where all fires are prohibited year round.

Pitt Meadows doesn't allow campfires in any part of the city.

(CP) - Poor communication was one of the biggest problems during last summer's Garnet forest fire, says an independent review of the blaze.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Price Waterhouse report into the handling of the fire that destroyed 18 Penticton area homes, forced 3,000 residents to flee and blackened 5,500 hectares of forest, were released Friday.</p><p>Consultant Mike MacCallum singled out poor communication with the public on July 25, when strong winds reversed direction and blew the flames towards homes in the Upper Carmi area five days after the fire began.</p><p>"People were definitely lulled into a false sense of security,'' he told a news conference.</p><p>"We believe that the evacuation of Upper Carmi could have and should have been initiated sooner,'' says the report. "There was a two-and-a-half hour time lag between the Forest Service evacuating its own crews and notification of the Carmi residents of the revised fire status.''</p><p>Although the fire command did not believe the blaze would jump the Ellis Creek canyon, the consultants say they should have considered that possibility.</p><p>Instead, residents received an evacuation order, which left little time to ensure everyone was safely moved from the area.</p><p>"There was a very real potential for serious injury or death, and the fact that no lives were lost, is due largely to friends and neighbours notifying one another,'' the report said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - About 100 firefighters worked Thursday to try to control a blaze in valuable Crown timber on Mount Brenton.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The forest fire grew to about 35 hectares Thursday, although fire guards had been built around one-third of it.</p><p>"We've cooled it down a lot with all the iron we had flying around yesterday,'' said forest service spokesman Tim Neal.</p><p>Six bucket-equipped helicopters continued to drop water on the fire's hot spots all day, but the two giant Martin Mars water bombers returned to their base on Vancouver Island.</p><p>"There are no big flames,'' forest service spokeswoman Leslie Laird said Thursday night. "It is just kind of smoldering at this point.</p><p>"We have been fortunate with the winds today. We have not had heavy winds at all.''</p><p>Three 20-member forest service crews were fighting the blaze, plus about 30 workers from Pacific Forest Products and MacMillan Bloedel.</p><p>The total firefighting force is almost double the ground crew that hit the fire on its first full day Wednesday.</p><p>Cause of the fire is still under investigation.</p><p>In spite of a flurry of fires this week, 1996 hasn't been a bad year for forest fires. The coastal district has had 135 fires, which burned 295 hectares. Last year by the same date, 229 fires had burned 257.1 hectares.</p><p>Provincewide, 976 fires have been recorded this season, compared with 1,188 by the corresponding time in 1995 and 3,038 in The Department of Health has the air and road ambulance people on standby.''</p><p>So far, Adams-Bower said, no moves have been made to evacuate whole towns or villages in the path of the fires.</p><p>Saskatchewan fire officials said Thursday there are 63 fires burning in the province, 11 are listed as being out of control.</p><p>The village most at risk is La Loche, where a forest fire is burning about eight kilometres from the town.</p><p>There are several small fires burning near the community of 1,600, most were started during a lightning storm earlier this week.</p><p>The Ile-a-la-Crosse blaze, which is burning about 10 kilometres south of the village, has consumed about 7.6 square kilometres of tinder-dry timber is the biggest fire in the region.</p><p>Ile-a-la-Crosse is under no immediate threat because it's separated from the fire by an arm of the Churchill River.</p><p>Adams-Bower says her department will team up with the Red Cross to provide evacuation and registration centres if evacuations are ordered.</p><p>If there are members of the public who have to be evacuated and they don't have a family member or a friend's place to go to, then they can go to our reception centre which could be in a school gym or a gym on a reserve if there is one close.</p><p>"They register with the Red Cross and then our staff works to relocate them in a safe place if they have to be there for any length of time and ensure they have the necessities of life, that sort of thing.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Gonen said it would take several days to identify precisely which plots had been affected.</p><p>The fire, which forced the closing of Israel's main highway for six hours on Sunday, injured 37 people with smoke inhalation. There were no fatalities.</p><p>The flames were whipped up by high winds on the hottest day of the year, skipping over stands of trees or pockets of flowers, but threatening neighboring hotels. While the blaze was confined to a relatively small area by Canadian standards, it dealt a strong psychological blow in a country where most trees are planted by hand and take years to mature.</p><p>Hundreds of residents were forced to flee rural communities in the area. More than half of the 50 homes in Shoresh, 10 kilometres west of Jerusalem, were destroyed. Area residents fled by car and on foot as the flames drew nearer.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source (CP) - Students at the B.C. Institute of Technology can stand in the midst of a raging forest fire without getting a hair singed.</p><p nitf:lede="true">In the school's fire simulation training centre, one of only two in North America, screens and speakers surround forestry students with the sights and sounds of a real forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The idea is to put them as close into the real thing as possible,'' said fire boss Robin Lihou, who teaches a fire management course.</p><p>From a control room at the back of a lecture theatre, the simulator projects fire images onto a giant screen at the front. Flames roar through speakers at a volume of 5,000 watts.</p><p>The student is given a walkie talkie to communicate with other role players. Up to eight other role players may share the theatre and the student's every move is followed by an audience of classmates.</p><p>The exersize tests decision-making, communication, budget-control and observation skills.</p><p>"The idea is to imply a stress load,'' said Lihou. "Some people perform well under stress. Others don't.''</p><p>In the control room, the student's requests are translated into on-screen action.</p><p>Helicopters, water bombers or busloads of firemen can be brought into the two-dimensional blaze with the click of a computer mouse.</p><p>For the successful student, the program ends with the fire reduced to tendrils of smoke. In the background, healthy trees stretch into sunshine.</p><p>The simulator is worth about $300,000. Laser disc technology allows operators to access any of 108,000 frames in about a fifth of a second.</p><p>In its two years of operation, about 1,200 student hours have been logged on the system.</p><p>But students aren't the only ones who benefit from the program.</p><p>The Forest Ministry's crew, sector and fire bosses also use the simulator to polish their skills at the beginning of fire season.</p><p>"It's just to keep them thinking fire,'' said Lihou.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (Alberta)</p><p>The only highway into Fort McMurray, Alberta has again been cut off by thick smoke.</p><p>Ground crews lost control of one corner of the 78-thousand-hectare blaze.</p><p>There's no word when the route will re-open. (NWT)</p><p>A second wave of 200 people managed to leave Norman Wells, Northwest Territories after light winds blew thick smoke away from the airport.</p><p>Yesterday, they flew to Yellowknife about 700 kilometres to the south.</p><p>About 400 women, children and elderly people left the oil town last Thursday as a raging fire raced through the forest nearby.</p><p>The wind co-operated by blowing the flames away from the hamlet.</p><p>The 350 people who left Fort Norman on Tuesday were assured their hamlet is safe for now.</p><p>Monster flames had come to the edge of the community. (Manitoba)</p><p>Manitoba firefighters are also poised to strike new fires if the weather turns.</p><p>Forestry officer Dick Bon says only two fires are out of control.</p><p>However, he says firefighters should get the upper hand soon. urn:contentItem:5SX4-MMD1-JDH3-G113-00000-00UPDATE: Parry Sound 33 fire activity increases due to lake effect winds2018-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:06ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1UPDATE: Parry Sound 33 fire activity increases due to lake effect winds

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 a.m. Wednesday, July 25): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Fire has expanded Northeast region restricted fire zone.

Due to strong, warmer and drier lake effect winds the ministry required aerial fire suppression yesterday, July 25, as fire activity increased. As a result of the the southwest winds, smoke was pushed across Highway 69 and into some communities to the east of the fire.

Resources yesterday included CL415 water bombers, two bird dog aircraft, heavy helicopters T802 amphibious aircraft and ground crews, the ministry reports.

Additional crews from Mexico arrived on the fire today, bringing the total number of firefighters helping to suppress the fire to 90. Values protection, or sprinklers, will continue to be put in place on structures along the Pickerel River today.

"Given the unpredictability of the fire, all access restrictions, including water restrictions, remain in place for the foreseeable future," reads a ministry press release. "In the interest of public safety, on July 21, 2018 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF)'s Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area below impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only: All areas ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay."

There is also a recommendation by the ministry Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

By the evening of July 25 there were 50 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 16 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were two new fires confirmed in the region today. Hearst 14, located approximately 42 kilometres south of Hearst, is two hectares and not yet under control. Two crews provided initial attack on the fire with aerial suppression support. Wawa 11 is being held at 0.1 hectares 75 kilometres southeast of Longlac.

(Tuesday, July 24, 11:10 p.m.):The fire is expected to remain relatively quiet for the next couple of days.

"However, fire conditions and behaviour can change quickly. Crews continue to monitor weather and fire behaviour closely. Residents will see smoke in the area as crews continue suppression efforts. Values protection have been put in place in Key Harbour, along parts of the south side of Pickerel River and along a portion of the train tracks east of the fire."

A total of eight helicopters worked the fire on July 24.

As of July 24 the fire was at 5,612 hectares and still not under control.

The cause of the fire was originally stated as "human" on the MNR's website but that classification has since been removed, McCool said, to avoid public speculation.

"Because the cause is still unknown at this time and it is under investigation."

(11:59 p.m., Monday, July 23): The Key River forest fire, known as Parry Sound 33, is now covering an area of 5,612 hectares and the restricted fire zone has been expanded to north of Rosseau.

According to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, Parry Sound 33 saw aerial fire suppression again on Monday, July 23. CL415s dropped water on the fire which was remapped at 5,612 hectares. Three heavy helicopters bucketed water to reduce the fire's intensity and co-ordinated with ground crews.

On July 21, the MNRF's Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only.

There is also a recommendation by the MNRF Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

In addition, the MNRF's Sudbury district has recommended that all residents along Hartley Bay Road be placed on an evacuation alert, pending changes to the fire situation.

The Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) and Conservation Officers have been on site helping notify the public of the situation, and facilitating this evacuation.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services (AFFES) has also been advised by Ontario Parks that the French River Provincial Park is fully closed west of Highway 69/400. All campers have been or are being evacuated. Ontario Parks has also suspended permit sales for the French River Delta and Pickerel River areas and are restricting entry to park users (everything west of Highway 69/400).

Henvey Inlet First Nation declared a state of emergency as a precautionary measure. As of July 22, the community has successfully and safely evacuated all of its community members, who are receiving accommodation and food.

Due to the extreme fire hazard and the large number of wildfires burning, the MNRF has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone to include some areas of the southern region. The new zone includes areas north of the community of Rosseau, northwest to Caramat, over to the Quebec border along Hwy 11 (to north of Abitibi Canyon) and southeast to Renfrew. This includes Algonquin Park, Parry Sound, Lake Superior Provincial Park, the North Shore of Lake Huron, Wawa, and Hearst. To check out more specific boundaries, visit Ontario.ca/forestfire and click on the interactive fire map.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris, is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions.

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ontario MNRF expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

By the evening of July 23 there were 55 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 21 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There was only one new start in the region today. Sudbury 92 located near Johnnie Lake in Killarney Provincial Park covers 0.1 of a hectare and is already under control.

TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, 2018, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of Parry Sound District where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity from Parry Sound 33.

The order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions. This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

All travel and use on the French River waterway, Pickerel River (West of Hwy 69/400), Henvey Inlet, Key River basin, and all associated tributaries that access these river systems, including all access from Georgian Bay, and all islands on Georgian Bay within the French River Provincial Park boundaries, Dokis Island system, and Puddick island and all islands north of Henvey Inlet near shore is prohibited.

All access roads west of Hwy 69/400, from Henvey Inlet north to the French River area are closed.

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for nonrecreational purposes, please call to 705-746-4201 to request a travel authorization permit. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

For information about the fire situation: 705-564-6165

For inquiries about French River Provincial Park restrictions: 705-857-1630 ext 224

For Parry Sound District information, including all calls related to the recommendation of these evacuations and alerts, call 705-773-4218.

For updates on highway conditions, including closures, please call 5-1-1.

urn:contentItem:5SWG-T981-F105-62YP-00000-00Key River forest fire fight continues with help from peers in Canada, Mexico, U.S.2018-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:06ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Key River forest fire fight continues with help from peers in Canada, Mexico, U.S.

HENVEY INLET FIRST NATION - UPDATE (Monday, July 23, 2:30 p.m.): The rain helped.

The 5,000-hectare fire that caused evacuations in Henvey Inlet First Nation, Key River and Killarney is being held back by firefighters with some help from Mother Nature, according to Shayne McCool, fire information officer for the Ministry of Natural Resources Northeast region.

Estimates from Environment Canada are the region saw 3.5 millimetres of rain in the last 24 hours.

McCool cautions that as the sun shines and the humidity goes down, the fire could regroup.

Evacuation notices remain in place, although currently smoke conditions are much less severe. There are no highway closures today.

McCool confirmed there are volunteers fighting the fire from all across Canada, the United States and from as far away as Mexico.

Residents in Henvey Inlet First Nation have been safely evacuated, according to a press release on Monday, July 23, from the reserve. As a precautionary measure, the chief and council officially declared a State of Emergency on July 21 due to the smoke from the fire.

"The community is not in imminent danger. Leadership decided to call a State of Emergency and evacuate the community because we want to ensure the safety of the community," said Chief Wayne McQuabbie. "We're also protecting homes and properties. We'll ensure the safety of the community until there is no more potential danger."

Members are reportedly safe and being accommodated in Parry Sound and Sudbury.

Kayla McQuabbie of Henvey Inlet First Nation was evacuated Saturday evening and was sent to stay at a hotel in Sudbury.

She returned to her Henvey home Monday, July 23 to pick up her dogs, but was returning to Sudbury. McQuabbie said it wasn't particularly smoky when she visited her home, but said it all depends on the way the wind is going.

"It was scary at first, but then afterwards when we knew that everybody was taken care of it was good."

McQuabbie said about 80 people from her community were evacuated and she was told that she may be able to return home as soon as Friday.

UPDATE (Monday, July 23, 11 a.m.): French River Provincial Park, west of Highway 69 is closed. The Visitor Centre is also closed to the public until further notice.

On Monday morning, July 23 at the French River Trading Post, there is no smoke or fire visible and there is no smell of smoke either. The Trading Post closed early on Saturday, July 21, but has since reopened.

French River Trading Post employee Lorraine Dowland was evacuated at Pickerel River Road. People coming through have said they have been evacuated from French River area.

Rob Stuckless, who lives at Henvey Inlet First Nation, returned from vacation at around 7 p.m. on Saturday to learn he was under an evacuation notice. He said if he was given the choice, he would have stayed behind because he wasn't concerned for his property. He is now staying with a friend.

Those wishing to stay, despite the evacuation, have been asked to sign a waiver.

"Fire wouldn't have bothered me," said Stuckless, who lives on the opposite side of the highway from the fire. "I heard that down in Key River, they didn't lose any cottages, but down at the bottom end of the Pickerel River, there's a few gone."

Yesterday, Sunday, July 22, he was allowed to return his and gather a few more things.

The fire that started a little more than four days ago in the Key River area is still not under control.

Earlier Sunday evening, July 22, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry said the fire had spread to cover an area of approximately 5,000 hectares.

Key River residents were under a mandatory evacuation order in the afternoon of Friday, July 20 and members of the Henvey Inlet First Nation community were under mandatory evacuation on Saturday, July 21.

All road access properties in the area of the fire are under a 12-hour notice of evacuation order.

A significant amount of smoke continues along Highway 69 south of Grundy Lake Provincial Park.

If you're travelling, plan to avoid the areas of Highway 69 in the Key River and Henvey Inlet First Nation areas.

More information will be posted as it becomes available.

For Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry updates on the fire, visit ontario.ca/page/forest-fires.

urn:contentItem:5T14-8KH1-JDH3-G316-00000-00All hiking and biking trails closed on Maple Mountain due to wildfire2018-08-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:06ZLexisNexisNEWSAll hiking and biking trails closed on Maple Mountain due to wildfire

All trail heads to North Cowichan's Maple Mountain, and select trails on Mount Richards that are close to Maple Mountain, are closed until further notice due to the ongoing forest fire near Crofton.

Natasha Horsman, a spokeswoman for the Municipality of North Cowichan that owns the municipal forest reserve which includes Maple Mountain, said that in the past 30 years, Maple Mountain has only been closed to foot, bike, and horse access a single time, which occurred in 2003.

Interface fires across the province during the dry and hot summer of 2003 caused unprecedented damage and disruption.

"This was done because North Cowichan had allocated fire fighting resources to the Interior, leaving us unable to manage forest fires within our reserve," Horsman said.

Horsman said the municipality does not close the forest reserve to non-motorized access unless there is an emergency event going on, and access to trail heads in other areas of the municipal forest reserve, including Mount Richards, Stoney Hill and Mount Tzouhalem, remain open at this time.

"Having the public's eyes and ears on the ground in our MFR assists us in wildfire response," she said.

"Members of the public out hiking or biking in the MFR are often the first people to either call in a wildfire or take proactive steps to prevent a wildfire, allowing us to respond quicker than waiting for smoke to be seen visibly rising from the forest."

RELATED STORY: MAPLE MOUNTAIN STILL BURNING

As for motorized vehicles, Horsman said the gates on forestry roads on Maple Mountain, Mount Richards, Stoney Hill and Mount Tzouhalem are permanently closed, and are only opened for specific times and events with the municipality's approval.

She said Mount Prevost and Mount Sicker are the only mountains where forestry-road gates are open on a regular basis for motorized access, but these gates have been closed since July 17 this year, due to the wildfire risk.

The TimberWest forest company has announced that it is also closing the gates on all its forest lands on Vancouver Island, and ceased company operations, until the forest fire risk subsides.

Island Timberlands has also closed all public access to its private forest lands until further notice.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Tuesday, Aug. 7, 9:40 p.m.): Though not yet under control, according to the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, Parry Sound 33 had no new growth Tuesday, August 7. The fire is holding at 11,362 hectares.

Crews continue to work the perimeter and containment around the fire is almost complete. The total perimeter is almost 120 kilometers long. There are 275 firefighters and support staff currently working on this incident. That number will continue to fluctuate as staff complete their 14 day assignment and more staff become available after days of rest.

By the evening of August 7, there were 43 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 14 are not yet under control, 29 are either being held, under control or being observed.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Tuesday, Aug. 7, 9:40 p.m.): Though not yet under control, according to the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, Parry Sound 33 had no new growth Tuesday, August 7. The fire is holding at 11,362 hectares.

Although this fire received approximately 10 millimetres of rain, extremely dry fuel conditions remain.

Firefighters took advantage of the precipitation, high humidity and low winds to continue consolidating hose lines around the perimeter. Crews continued to move inward to solidify control lines.

By the evening of Aug. 6, there were 44 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 18 are not yet under control, 26 are either being held, under control or being observed. There were four new fires confirmed on Monday, Aug. 6, two of which are already been called out, including Parry Sound 38, which was located south of Parry Sound 33. It was confirmed at 0.1 hectares and declared out on Monday, Aug. 6.

UPDATE (Sunday, Aug. 5, 10:55 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown once again, to 11,362 hectares and is still not yet under control.

RESTRICTED FIRE ZONES

Restricted fire zone has expanded to additional parts of the northeast fire region (southern region)

Due to the extreme fire hazard, several recent periods of heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire activity, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone to include parts of the southern region of Ontario as outlined on the interactive map. This expansion of the current Restricted Fire Zone will be in effect as of 12:01 a.m. on July 24, and will remain in place until further notice.

The expanded Restricted Fire Zone now includes Zones 24, 25, and 26 which would include areas south of the French River, including Parry Sound, from Georgian Bay east to the Quebec border, including Algonquin Provincial Park and from Renfrew north to Mattawa.

To date, the current MNRF Restricted Fire Zone covers Zones 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 24, 25, and 26 and restrictions will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for an outline of the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ontario Ministry of Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS

Travel restrictions in the Parry Sound and Sudbury districts have been expanded in the vicinity of the Parry Sound 33 fire. For details, visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, 2018, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of Parry Sound District where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity from Parry Sound 33.

The order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions. This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

All travel and use on the French River waterway, Pickerel River (West of Hwy 69/400), Henvey Inlet, Key River basin, and all associated tributaries that access these river systems, including all access from Georgian Bay, and all islands on Georgian Bay within the French River Provincial Park boundaries, Dokis Island system, and Puddick island and all islands north of Henvey Inlet near shore is prohibited.

All access roads west of Hwy 69/400, from Henvey Inlet north to the French River area are closed.

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for nonrecreational purposes, please call to 705-746-4201 to request a travel authorization permit. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

SMOKE CONCERNS

Smoke from large fires across the region will be visible until fire activity is reduced and weather patterns change.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services is reminding the public that if they do see flames or smoke, please report it, and stay away from the area in the interest of public safety.

If you have questions or concerns about smoke and your health, please contact Tele Health Ontario at 1-866-797-0000.

Restricted fire zone has expanded to additional parts of the northeast fire region (southern region)

Due to the extreme fire hazard, several recent periods of heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire activity, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone to include parts of the southern region of Ontario as outlined on the interactive map. This expansion of the current Restricted Fire Zone will be in effect as of 12:01 a.m. on July 24, and will remain in place until further notice.

The expanded Restricted Fire Zone now includes Zones 24, 25, and 26 which would include areas south of the French River, including Parry Sound, from Georgian Bay east to the Quebec border, including Algonquin Provincial Park and from Renfrew north to Mattawa.

To date, the current MNRF Restricted Fire Zone covers Zones 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 24, 25, and 26 and restrictions will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for an outline of the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ontario Ministry of Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

urn:contentItem:5WJ0-V291-F103-31PW-00000-00FireSmart sessions take place in Keremeos2019-07-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:06ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYFireSmart sessions take place in Keremeos

Embers from wildfires are the biggest fire hazards to homes and properties in Keremeos.

That's according to local FireSmart representative Brandy Maslowski, who delivered a Firesmart session to roughly 20 Keremeos residents on June 26.

"There's sort of a myth out there that a wall of flame is going to take out Keremeos but the reality is that the embers from a wildfire are what can really cause the damage," she said.

In Keremeos, she explained that homes are surrounded by orchards or dikes, which act as good fire breaks.

"It's not likely a fire will sweep through and take out the town. The likelihood is that homes will be affected by embers from a forest fire that could travel one or two kilometres and land on the property."

The focus of the session is to make the village safe from fires by encouraging residents to make their properties "ember safe." She said if there is a wildfire in the area, properties and homes that don't have any flammable materials will less likely burn if an ember lands.

"If you have a good roof, which means not a wood shingle roof, and you fire smart your property up to 10 metres, the statistics show that you have a 90 per cent chance of your home surviving a wildfire."

Some of the FireSmart methods involve changing the vegetation and plants around homes and removing fire hazards.

"We talk about changing the conifer trees on their yard to deciduous trees or taking woodpiles or piles of brush or things that are flammable like furniture and things, take them in if there is a wildfire in your area. You know clear up your property so there is nothing flammable," she said.

READ MORE: UPDATE: Three new fires sparked in the South Okanagan- Similkameen

As part of the session, Maslowski said forest fire experts looked at the community to determine where the risks are. While they concluded that the village was good shape to ward off wildfires, certain areas along Sykes Crescent, Vanderlinde Drive and Tweddle Street showed some risks. For example, she said there is a dike with some trees along it on Sykes Crescent and Vanderlinde Drive has a high quantity of ceder and the type of plants that are flammable.

"The main message we want to get out is why homes burn," she said. "We want to break that barrier of forest becoming a fire in the home so it is really is as simple as if you don't have anything flammable on your home, your home won't burn down. If private residents do private work on their own properties, they can really make a difference."

Later in the summer, Maslowski said a large demonstration on wildfire prevention methods will take place around one of the government buildings to show how to make the building fire safe. While the exact date has not yet been determined, she said it will likely take place at the end of July or beginning of August.

The money for the sessions come from a $50,000 grant funded by the Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development, and administered by the Union of BC Municipalities.

(CP) - The forest fire that has caused several days of havoc for firefighters northeast of here was likely started by humans, officials say.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Ministry of Natural Resources investigators have ruled out lightning as the cause of a fire burning over 250 square kilometres.</p><p>Dave Jackson, fire information officer for the ministry, said lightning detectors did not pick up any lightning strikes two days prior to April 30, when the fire was reported.</p><p>"We are investigating into the cause, but it looks to be human caused,'' said Jackson.</p><p>He said Thursday was a good day for firefighters because the fire didn't expand and there was time to attack it in several ways.</p><p>Crews were busy laying hose line around the perimeter of the fire and establishing new bulldozer lines.</p><p>"It's hoped that this fire line will create a fire break. What happens is the bulldozer removes vegetation (and top soil) and leaves a sandy area underneath. When the fire hits this sand area, it usually doesn't go any further,'' said Jackson.</p><p>Two water bombers also worked steadily bombing the hot spots.</p><p>But the news was not all good. No rain is expected for at least five days, and the predicted sunshine, warm temperatures, low humidity and breezy conditions are perfect breeding fields for forest fires.</p><p>"This weather represents a challenge for us. A combination of these conditions dries the forest out. This will make the fire become more active,'' said Jackson.</p><p>Because of the weather forecast, the ministry has extended a restricted fire ban that was to end Thursday night.</p><p>With the opening of many provincial parks this weekend, the decision was a tough one, said Jackson.</p><p>"But under these circumstances, I think it was the right one.''</p><p>The fire ban, which takes in the area between the Manitoba border and the west side of Lake Nipigon, could be extended to the east side of Nipigon if the dry weather conditions continue.</p><p>Across the region, Fort Frances, Kenora, Dryden and Thunder Bay are all listed as high fire hazards.</p><p>Meanwhile, firefighters are still putting out hotspots from a forest fire in Timmins. That city will have to pick up the tab for at least $22,000 to cover the cost of Natural Resources fire crews.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) _ Being surrounded by water was no protection from a raging forest fire as hundreds of residents from a First Nations community in northern Ontario were forced from their homes on Sunday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire swept over 30,000 hectares of land and eventually came too close to Kasabonika, a small community on an island in Kasabonika Lake, about 600 kilometres north of Thunder Bay, Ont.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>By Sunday evening, the entire population _ over 700 residents _ had been evacuated by planes from the town, said Bob Pinder, spokesman for the emergency response team in charge of the evacuation. The residents are being housed in a community centre in the nearby city of Greenstone.</p><p>"They were worried about their homes being burnt,'' said Pinder, who added that none of the homes or buildings had been damaged as of Sunday night.</p><p>"It's a very remote, traditional community,'' said Pinder, who spoke to Kasabonika residents through an interpreter, because many of the community's elders speak only Ojibway.</p><p>Pinder said the community of Greenstone was well-equipped to handle the emergency _ bus loads of Kasabonika children were taken to a nearby lake to swim during Sunday's heat, and Kasabonika teens were hired as monitors to make sure everyone's needs were met.</p><p>Deb MacLean, a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Natural Resources, said it could be as long as two weeks before Kasabonika residents could return home.</p><p>She said the main priority of the fire prevention team in Kasabonika was "values protection''. The team had already installed sprinklers on buildings in the town should the fire engulf the area. "It's going to be a long-term effort,'' MacLean said.</p><p>Lightning strikes ignited the fire on June 17, and MacLean said lack of precipitation during fall and winter months had made the forests in northwest Ontario very susceptible to fire.</p><p>"We've really entered early summer with underlying prevailing dry conditions,'' MacLean said.</p><p>A smaller fire burning near Ignace, Ont., about 200 kilometres northwest of Thunder Bay, forced the evacuation of a tourist resort and some cottages.</p><p>On Saturday, that fire forced the closure of the Trans-Canada Highway, but one lane was open on Sunday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5WHB-8FB1-JBVR-30PF-00000-00Fire forcing evacuation of Keewaywin First Nation in northwestern Ontario2019-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:06ZLexisNexisNATIONAL,ONTARIOFire forcing evacuation of Keewaywin First Nation in northwestern OntarioKeewaywin First Nation evacuated as fire ragesColin PerkelThe Canadian Press

A raging forest fire in northwestern Ontario has prompted the full evacuation of the First Nation community of Keewaywin, authorities said on Thursday.

More than 200 residents considered vulnerable had already been flown this week to Sioux Lookout, Ont., as the fire moved closer, while roughly 200 more were being sent to another city Thursday.

Joe Meekis, a former long-time chief of Keewaywin - which has about 450 residents - called the situation scary.

"The community is threatened," Meekis said in an interview from Sioux Lookout. "Everybody has to get out."

Known as Red Lake Fire Number 23, the blaze which is now about 546 square kilometres began as a small fire a week ago about 40 kilometres from the community. Earlier this week, the winds picked up and it "grew really fast," Meekis said.

Smoke began drifting into the community, prompting residents to close windows and doors, and shut down air conditioners.

Ultimately, the chief declared an emergency and the initial transfer of babies, pregnant women, and children under five and their families began. On Tuesday and Wednesday, a total of 227 people were flown about 330 kilometres south to Sioux Lookout, which has declared its own state of emergency aimed at defraying the cost of helping the arrivals.

Volunteers in the town were helping provide access to snacks, supplies and information, as well as responding to requests from the evacuees, a spokesman said.

"All evacuees are being housed at a local hotel, and a local restaurant is providing all of the meals," said Brian MacKinnon, the town's manager of corporate services. "(However), Sioux Lookout is presently at capacity with respect to the number of evacuees we can host."

As a result, the more than 200 remaining evacuees were being flown to Timmins, Ont., on Thursday, leaving just a skeleton crew in the community for security purposes, Meekis said.

"They're moving people today, as we speak," Meekis said.

By noon Thursday, the fire was 10 kilometres southwest of the Keewaywin boundary, which is 12 kilometres from the town itself, according to the provincial Ministry of Natural Resources.

Jonathan Scott, an information officer with Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, said an incident management team was on site looking for "aerial ignition opportunities" in which fires are deliberately set to take the blaze to natural barriers and slow its spread. Crews and equipment were also in the area.

Despite some isolated heavy rains Wednesday night, the fire hazard in the region ranged from low to extreme. Speaking from Dryden, Ont., Scott said 12 new smaller fires were confirmed on Wednesday near Red Lake, Fort Frances, Dryden and Sioux Lookout.

In all, more than two dozen fires are burning in northwestern Ontario, 12 out of control.

Large numbers of huge forest fires are not unusual in the region. There have been 183 to date this season, well below the 500 of last year and about half the 10-year average of 366, Scott said.

Still, the fires pose a logistical challenge.

"Ontario is so stretched with their resources," Meekis said. "There's fires all over the place. So we have to sort of fight for the resources."

Keewaywin's last full evacuation occurred in 2011. While the community was spared, damage to the surrounding area was significant.

urn:contentItem:53C6-GG31-DYTG-Y3GT-00000-00Forest fire evacuees expected in region2011-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:06ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. B1Forest fire evacuees expected in regionBy Brent Davis, Record staffWATERLOO REGION

Communities in southern Ontario, including Waterloo Region and Arthur, are preparing for the arrival of hundreds of evacuees from the fire-ravaged north.

The first planeload of residents fleeing the forest fires bearing down on their isolated First Nations communities could touch down in Waterloo Region today.

Approximately 250 people are expected to be housed in Arthur, while another 150 will likely find temporary homes in residence buildings at the University of Waterloo.

On Wednesday, officials in Waterloo Region were awaiting formal confirmation that evacuees will be housed here.

"We're prepared and we're waiting for the call from Emergency Measures Ontario to be at the airport to pick them up," said the region's director of corporate communications, Bryan Stortz.

Some of the evacuees may be elderly or have health concerns, so the region has ensured that some of the accommodations at the university are more accessible.

A group from Sandy Lake First Nations were expected Wednesday at the community centre in Arthur, but their departure was delayed

"They weren't able to get them out because the flames were really intensifying," Wellington County communications officer Andrea Ravensdale said.

A total of 3,300 people have been forced from their homes in about 19 First Nations communities in northwestern Ontario. Military planes flew many of the residents into Thunder Bay. Evacuation centres in places like Dryden and Sioux Lookout are filling up, prompting the need to look south. Commercial planes will likely be used to bring evacuees to Waterloo Region.

There were 112 active fires burning on Wednesday, and some 2,000 firefighters are battling the blazes, sparked by dry weather and more than 35,000 lightning strikes.

Ontario Natural Resources Minister Linda Jeffrey said the area burned is almost five times as large as the average area consumed by fires in the province every year.

This isn't the first time the region has thrown open its doors in a time of crisis. In 2008, about 125 residents from Attawapiskat were brought here as flooding forced more than 1,000 people from their homes in the James Bay area.

"We learned a lot," Stortz said. "Our experience last time was quite positive."

Agencies including the region's social services and public health departments, the Canadian Red Cross, the Salvation Army, the City of Waterloo, the Community Care Access Centre and the university will partner in the effort. The federal government will reimburse the region for all costs incurred.

But too often, the fire gets away from railway crews, the ministry contends.</p><p>Last year, a forest fire at Terrace Bay, 220 kilometres (137 miles) northeast of Thunder Bay, prompted the evacuation of 400 people for four hours and threatened the Lake Superior town of 2,500.</p><p>The ministry said railway workers caused the fire and billed CP Rail $174,000.</p><p>The railway has refused to pay that bill, saying it wants to negotiate the amount. The ministry has decided to take CP to court.</p><p>Last Friday, a tank with one million litres of diesel fuel caught fire at Sioux Lookout, about 260 kilometres (162 miles) northwest of Thunder Bay after a grass fire set by CN Rail crews ignited spillage from the tank.</p><p>Fire permits previously were issued from April 1 to Oct. 31.</p><p>Peter Gagnon, fire prevention officer with the ministry's Aviation and Fire Centre in Sault Ste. Marie, said his office has done a provincewide assessment and decided all railway property needs a cleanup of brush, grass, lumber and fuels that might pose a fire Editor, The News:

Re: Notes from the forest fire zone.

Too bad Tom Fletcher is back.

His Aug. 16 column is once again filled with the usual misinformation and outright lies.

He chides local media for being bored with their coverage of "far-off towns and farms," yet further on he quotes forest fire stats for all of Canada.

He talks about coverage of the individual folks who suffered from the fires and no coverage for the firefighters. I guess he missed the coverage I saw of the firefighters.

His most ridiculous comments are regarding Al Gore's largely optimistic new movie, as if it will be filled with Fletcher's claim of "inaccurate" predictions in the 2006 movie.

In fact, the Arctic is sufficiently ice-free that cruise ship companies are scheduling cruises there. A large piece of the ice sheet in Antarctica did break off not long ago and Greenland glaciers are melting back at an alarming rate.

More misinformation from Mr. Fletcher.

He says the area burned in B.C. this year "won't even be close to the record in 1958." Actually, more has been burned and we still have fires burning out of control.

Mr. Fletcher should give up his membership in the reactionary flat-earth society and pay attention to the real news of the extremely rapid global warming that is happening all around us.

Or, better yet, he should join the Donald Trump publicity hacks in their effort to promote alternate facts.

Will Leipert

"When a fire gets this size, it creates its own winds.</p><p>"We have evacuated some people from the south-side residences in the area.''</p><p>Altogether 12 families were ordered to leave their homes due to think clouds of acrid smoke.</p><p>"There is a lot of smoke. If there is a wind shift, the fires could encroach the residences themselves.''</p><p>Doug and Maureen Schiller and their sister-in-law Rachel scrambled to gather their farm animals and keepsakes before leaving.</p><p>"I'm packing up wedding pictures, wedding albums, my husband's baby book, anything I can't replace,'' Rachel Schiller said as she watched the flames off in the distance.</p><p>"People are taking our cattle for us. And we don't even care where they go. We've had to move out 45 head and their calves.''</p><p>Farmer Elwin Whyte said the flames were shooting 30 metres in the air within a few kilometres from his wheat and barley operation as the fire leaped from treetop to treetop.</p><p>Whyte sent his wife and younger children to safety but stayed behind with an older son to dig trenches and water down outbuildings.</p><p>He said the situation was "pretty scary.''</p><p>"I was worried. You get quite excited.''</p><p>The fire broke out Wednesday near a CN rail line. The cause of the blaze was still under investigation.</p><p>The area is mainly wooded hills and farmland. Drought conditions and moderate winds have made it difficult to contain the fire.</p><p>Hundreds of gas wells are in the area, but they were shut down as a precaution before the flames got too close.</p><p>More than 160 firefighters and several helicopters were battling the blaze.</p><p>A total of 17 fires were burning in the province Friday.</p><p>The dry conditions prompted the province to extend a ban on open fires from a line between Peace River and Lac la Biche in northern Alberta to points just above the U.S. border.</p><p>"The continued drying trend will result in a buildup of high to extreme forest fire hazard conditions,'' said a provincial release. "These conditions will increase the potential for out-of-control fires.''</p><p>So far this spring Alberta has received only trace amounts of moisture instead of normal rainfall levels of between 50 and 100 millimetres.</p><p>Major rivers south of northern Alberta are running at three-quarters to less than half of normal water levels.</p><p>The lack of moisture and a near record low mountain snowpack, coupled with a dry winter and two previous dry summers, have officials bracing for one of the worst agricultural droughts since the 1930s.</p><p>"Almost 90 per cent of the provincial agriculture area doesn't have enough soil moisture for annual cropping this year,'' said Alberta Agriculture spokesman Lloyd Andruchow.</p><p>"These conditions are threatening to impact what is a $7-billion primary agricultural industry in Alberta.''</p><p>The government is expected to announce additional drought support programs if the province doesn't receive significant rainfall by the end of June.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) _ About 275 people returned to their northern Alberta homes Friday after officials determined a forest fire threat to their community had lessened.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"I'm going to watch the Young and the Useless,'' laughed Rubina McDonald, 53, as she made her way back to her house. "I'll do a rain dance.''</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>A joyous Barbara Faichney got off a bus, her hands in the air.</p><p>"It's good to be back home. I felt like I was stuck in McMurray.''</p><p>Residents of Fort MacKay had been staying in nearby Fort McMurray since their hamlet was evacuated Wednesday afternoon. Officials told them Friday morning the fire hadn't burned any closer to Fort MacKay and prevailing winds were likely to blow smoke away from the community.</p><p>Wildfire information officer Patrick Loewen said firefighters have made some headway beating back the perimeters of the fire, so officials felt confident in recommending the residents go home. However, the danger is not over, he cautioned.</p><p>"We're more confident today that they have the opportunity to re-enter the community,'' Loewen said. "However, they will still be on an immediate evacuation alert.''</p><p>Angela McGonigal of the Regional Municipality of Wood Buffalo said Friday that evacuees who had spent the night in tent city set up at a Fort McMurray hockey arena passed the time playing cards or watching movies.</p><p>They were glad to get the all-clear signal, McGonigal said.</p><p>"There's certainly some anticipation there, but Fort MacKay is a community that understands the risks associated with living in a forested area,'' she said.</p><p>Loewen said an above-ground fire hydrant system and sprinklers would remain in place to protect homes until the fire danger passes.</p><p>The blaze has burned just under five square kilometres and came within four kilometres of Fort MacKay, Loewen said. It has not burned any homes but did cause some damage to the community's electrical system, which was expected to be repaired by Friday afternoon.</p><p>Fred Baehl, emergency preparedness director for the regional municipality, said the evacuation alert and the state of emergency will remain in place until all risk to the community is gone.</p><p>Fort MacKay is about 400 kilometres north of Edmonton.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20030620CPCPG1106</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2003</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:48WN-N0J0-01G6-937R-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="364"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2003 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="20" month="06" year="2003"><dateText>June 20, 2003 Friday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>FORESTRY; (CP) - Ontario's forest fire situation worsened Monday as crews from across the country arrived to help battle the spreading flames.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The last of more than 130 firefighters from British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan arrived in northeastern Ontario on Monday.</p><p>Four waterbombers from the Northwest Territories and an additional 150 contract firefighters from Ontario were also called in as shifting winds and hot, dry conditions fuelled the flames.</p><p>"The winds have been constantly shifting around,'' said Rob Grant, a Natural Resources Ministry technician, who added the weather is making the fires unpredictable and dangerous.</p><p>Officials warn the forests are tinder dry and lightning is expected to move in from the north by Thursday.</p><p>More than 47 fires are raging across the province with the bulk of them burning near Timmins, Kirkland Lake and Cochrane.</p><p>Crews are focusing on a 900-hectare fire about 30 kilometres northeast of Iroquois Falls and a 900-hectare fire about 30 kilometres southeast of Timmins.</p><p>The Timmins fire, believed to have been ignited by lightning Saturday, is spreading at about 18 metres per minute, the ministry reported.</p><p>"Some of the flames were shooting 100 feet into the air,'' said Johnny Sinclair, a member of the provincial firefighting team.</p><p>The fire is encroaching on two trappers' cabins and several trailers. Crews have set up sprinkler systems on the cabins and around other valuable areas.</p><p>Some of the campers and cottagers who were evacuated Sunday from around Gibson Lake have been allowed to return, but Gibson Lake Road remains closed due to an extreme risk that the fire will head in that direction.</p><p>"We're letting some cottagers back in to Gibson,'' said Ben Legouffe, a ministry information officer. "But we're keeping them on a really short leash.''</p><p>It is expected a ban on all open fires in the northeast - which was to be lifted today - will be extended to at least Thursday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) _ Fire fighters from Alberta to Ontario began arriving in British Columbia on Friday to help backstop colleagues battling dozens of blazes across the province.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Currently, B.C. fire fighters are fully utilized,'' the B.C. Forest Service said in a news release.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fire officials got a better look at British Columbia's largest forest fire Friday and discovered it's bigger than they first thought.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>On Thursday, the fire was estimated to cover 13 square kilometres. By Friday morning, officials had revised that to 29 square kilometres _ about six times the size of Vancouver's Stanley Park _ after results from satellite mapping came in.</p><p> The fire inside was sort of burning in fingers,'' said Mitzi Bushell, of the B.C. Forest Service. The fingers have joined.''</p><p>Fire guards have been set up around 65 per cent of the blaze's perimeter, but wind and electrical storms in the weekend forecast are causing concern.</p><p>The fire remains active and aggressive,'' the forest service said.</p><p>The fire has been burning about 25 kilometres away from Princeton, a community of about 3,000 about 200 kilometres southeast of Vancouver.</p><p>However, the smoke is causing breathing difficulties for some Princeton residents.</p><p>About 200 fire service workers and 10 helicopters are battling the blaze. It's costing about $170,000 per day to fight it.</p><p>The fire was sparked last weekend after a motorhome caught fire on Highway 3.</p><p>Meanwhile, the fire hazard is increasing in many parts of the parched province.</p><p>Cathi Piazza, another spokeswoman for the forest service, said the forecast calls for warm dry conditions this weekend.</p><p> We are watching a system that may work its way into the province. We may get some more summer thunder storms. We're hoping for some rain, but there's always the possibility for more dry lightning.''</p><p>She said there are about 120 fires burning in British Columbia, most of them a result of lightning strikes.</p><p> Most of them are small, but one has reached 470 hectares,'' said Piazza.</p><p>A cluster of 18 fires is burning just east of Revelstoke.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Forest Service said Sunday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">However, smoke from two fires in Washington state and one in the Stein Valley northeast of Vancouver draped the Thompson, Okanagan and Similkameen valleys.</p><p>Wendy Stewart, a spokeswoman for the forest service, said aside from a number of small fires, it was a quiet weekend for fire crews.</p><p>The main trouble spot is the Stein Valley fire which flared again and now covers 1,000 hectares west of Lytton in the Fraser Canyon.</p><p>Much of the smoke is coming from a 1,080-hectare fire south of Manning Park in Washington state. The smoke has been hanging over Princeton and Keremeos, north of the border.</p><p>In addition, a fire near Omak, Wash., brought hazy skies to the Okanagan and Thompson valleys.</p><p>The Stein Valley fire has been difficult for crews because of rugged terrain, intense smoke and unsafe flying conditions for water bombers. Crews could not reach the hot spots on Sunday.</p><p>Stewart said winds are expected to increase by Tuesday which could alleviate some of the smoky conditions.</p><p>Meanwhile, another B.C. water bomber left Abbotsford, B.C., Sunday to help in the fight against forest fires in Oregon, one of which destroyed 19 houses and damaged six others near Bend.</p><p>A B.C. water bomber and a reconnaissance plane had already been loaned to Oregon firefighters.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Dec 26, 2019( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) Chilean authorities said Thursday that forest fires in the tourist port city of Valparaiso, which left dozens of families homeless at Christmas, were started deliberately.No one died in the blazes that broke out on Tuesday and burned 150 hectares (370 acres) of forest, leaving 12 volunteer firefighters injured and affecting around 700 people living in 245 homes.But the Public Ministry, which is investigating the cause of the fires that began on two hills, described them as "highly intentional."

"We have evidence from photos, videos and conversations with locals that those fires in Valparaiso were produced intentionally," said Agriculture Minister Antonio Walker.The Valparaiso area is hot and dry at this time of year, but the government believes several other fires that have broken out recently have been started deliberately.Chile's President Sebastian Pinera traveled to the area on Thursday to lead the investigation.The government has announced subsidies for those affected to build new houses.Due to its 44 hills, which are mostly difficult to access, and its dense vegetation, fires are quite common in Valparaiso, which lies 120 kilometers (75 miles) to the west of the capital Santiago.In 2014, 15 people died and more than 3,000 homes were destroyed in a huge forest fire.Walker said more than 15,000 hectares have been affected by forest fires since July 1, whereas only 4,500 hectares were destroyed last year.

urn:contentItem:5XTC-0NW1-JDH1-C1YF-00000-00Canadians give up Christmas to fight Aussie wildfires2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:06ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A8Canadians give up Christmas to fight Aussie wildfiresThe Canadian Press

Sixty-nine Canadians are giving up their holidays at home to join the battle for the first time against the deadly wildfires devastating vast tracts of several Australian states.

The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre says a contingent of 21 highly trained staff from a variety of agencies left Canada on Dec. 3, for a 38-day deployment in New South Wales after the centre received an official request for assistance.

On Dec. 19 a second group of 30 Canadians was sent in for a 38-day deployment in the fire zone, and a further 18 are leaving on Dec. 30 for about a month.

Kim Connors, the executive director of the Winnipeg based CIFFC, says that Canada has called on Australian firefighters four times since 2015, and the "agreements are reciprocal in nature so it was the first time that Australia has needed help from Canada."

"Our Canadian firefighters and their families have volunteered their time to be away for the holidays, which is different for the northern hemisphere to be dealing with wildland fires over Christmas and New Year's so we're very proud of them for doing that," he said in an interview.

The CIFFC says crews from Newfoundland and Labrador, Quebec, Yukon, Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and B.C. are assisting with a variety of tasks including roles in command and aviation.

Wind change reduces fire threat to gas plant</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>WHITEHORSE</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>WHITEHORSE (CP) - A change in wind direction has reduced the forest fire threat to an operating natural gas plant in the Kotaneelee gas fields in southwestern Yukon.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Plant operator Larry Macdonald of Anderson Exploration Ltd. said Wednesday reports from the Labiche River area indicate the wind is blowing out of the north and against the 22-hectare fire.</p><p>The blaze is located between one and 1.5 kilometres south of the plant.</p><p>Nonetheless, the Calgary-based company, which owns 33 per cent of the plant and operates it, is prepared to implement its emergency response plan.</p><p>That includes removing some workers, closing off wells and emptying underground pipelines running between the wells and the plant, Macdonald said.</p><p>"I understand the greatest peril was yesterday, and that the risk is somewhat reduced today because the wind is coming from the northwest,'' he said.</p><p>Keith Kepke, head of fire management for the Department of Northern Affairs, said the 30 or so firefighters battling the fire were able to keep it at bay Tuesday, with a minimal growth of two hectares.</p><p>"The big concern we will have out the next couple of days will be wind,'' Kepke said. "As long as they don't have any wind, they should be OK.''</p><p>Fire centre officials reported the fire was caused by loggers burning slash.</p><p>Macdonald said the plant produces about 35 million cubic metres of gas a day, or at least 10,000 times more than an average house would use on a cold winter day.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5WCR-F1S1-F103-31FK-00000-00Drought, climate change and fire refugees2019-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:06ZLexisNexisOPINIONDrought, climate change and fire refugees

To the editor;

Who's ready to become a forest-fire refugee? I'm not ready, are you?

A lot of opinion attributes the increased frequency and severity of B.C.'s forest fires to "climate 
change." Although climate change can be linked to these fires, it's more in a role as a catch-all explanation. However, global warming and drought are different. Drought is due to lack of water vapour in the atmosphere, whereas the cause of global warming is excess of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.

The B.C. government and its pet, the forest industry, have been doing everything possible to cause the present drought. More than 100 years of rapacious, clear cut logging is what's done the job. Each tree normally emits into the atmosphere many hundreds of litres of water vapour per day. When the trees are cut, this no longer happens and the atmospheric water deficit begins.

Each block that's clear cut now exposes its soil directly to sunlight. This soil warms up more than the surrounding forest and convection currents form in the lower atmosphere. Over the denuded landscape, the air rises and these currents now draw moist air from the surrounding forest, drying it out.

In the past, we may have retrieved some of this water vapour as rain, but today things are different. So much land has been logged and so much burned that the air aloft is dry. It's so dry that the water vapour brought upward by these convection currents doesn't come back as rain. So, the forest dries out, reducing the fitness of the remaining trees.

This is what's happening to the red cedar on the coast.

With each massive forest fire, new areas of bare soil are exposed. These will further dry out the environment with the convection currents that arise.

The situation is dreadful, but isn't hopeless. This drought hasn't been made in China, made in the US or anywhere else. It's been made in BC and with a huge effort, it can be corrected.

Clear cut logging needs to be stopped immediately. Then, armies of tree planters need to get to work replanting both the logged and burned areas. This could be a boost for forestry workers. For every job lost cutting trees, there should be 100 more jobs replanting them. For every trucking job lost, many more would be created growing and distributing seedlings.

The trees to be planted should follow nature's preference for succession; broadleaf aspens, alders and birch. These trees grow quickly, emit more water vapour than conifers and would shade the forest floor, keeping it cool and reducing harmful convection currents.

In B.C., drought shouldn't be explained solely by climate change. Drought is due to a lack of water vapour and our disappearing forests are the cause.

The Bank of Canada recently said that climate change, into which drought is now lumped, represents a severe financial risk. B.C.'s fire refugees know this too well. How long will it be before the politicians quit practising their silly walks and assume the action required?

Dave Simms,

Clearwater, B.C.
